keywords: White sturgeon, Upper Columbia River, Recruitment failure, Critically Endangered, IUCN, Canadian Species at Risk Act, UCWSRI, UCWSRP, Lake Roosevelt, Sturgeon Recovery Project, Natural recruitment, Annually.
abstract:
In order to monitor the health and population trends of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt, a collaborative effort is being made between various organizations including the Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative (UCWSRI) and the Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project. The primary method used for this monitoring is conducted through gill net surveys.

The necessity of these surveys arises from concerns over the Critically Endangered status of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam. With recruitment failure documented in the Transboundary Reach between Grand Coulee and HLK dams, it is essential to evaluate annual natural recruitment and the success of experimental larval releases.

During these gill net surveys, white sturgeon subyearling and yearling juveniles are caught and assessed for their health and growth. This information is crucial in understanding the population dynamics of this endangered species and identifying any trends or issues that may impact their long-term survival. The data obtained from these surveys will be analyzed by the Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project per their project protocol.

By standardizing, coordinating, and conducting gill net surveys simultaneously with efforts in the Keenleyside Reach and the Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project, researchers can effectively compare population trends between areas and ensure accurate data collection. This collaborative approach not only helps to document natural recruitment but also supports ongoing research aimed at restoring viable populations of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River.
value:
Investing money into monitoring annual natural recruitment of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt is essential for several reasons:

1. Conservation: The upper Columbia River subpopulation of white sturgeon is critically endangered, and understanding recruitment patterns is crucial for their conservation. Monitoring recruitment helps us assess the success of ongoing recovery efforts and identify any trends or issues that may require additional interventions.
2. Research: Data from annual recruitment monitoring can inform hypotheses related to post-hatch dispersal and survival of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt. This information is essential for developing effective strategies to restore and enhance white sturgeon populations.
3. Compliance with Legislation: The Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative (UCWSRI) was established under both the Endangered Species Act (ESA) and the Canadian Species at Risk Act (SARA). Monitoring annual natural recruitment is a critical component of the UCWSRP, ensuring compliance with these legislations.
4. Collaborative Efforts: The Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project and Keenleyside Reach surveys are coordinated with the Lake Roosevelt Subyearling White Sturgeon Gill Net Surveys. Standardizing and conducting these surveys simultaneously will lead to more comprehensive data collection and a better understanding of white sturgeon populations in the upper Columbia River system.

problem_statement: The problem the protocol is trying to solve is the persistent recruitment failure and potential extinction of the white sturgeon population in the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam, specifically in the Transboundary Reach between Grand Coulee and HLK dams. To address this issue, the protocol outlines Lake Roosevelt Subyearling White Sturgeon Gill Net Surveys to document annual natural recruitment and evaluate the relative survival of experimental larval releases as part of research to test hypotheses relating to post-hatch dispersal. The goal is to ensure the persistence and viability of naturally reproducing populations of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River and restore opportunities for beneficial use if feasible.

description:
The text describes efforts to monitor and assess the recruitment of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt, located in the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam. White sturgeon in this area are classified as Critically Endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) and endangered under Canadian Species at Risk Act due to persistent recruitment failure. Recruitment failure was first documented in the Transboundary Reach, the area between Grand Coulee and HLK dams, during surveys of both the Keenleyside Reach in British Columbia and the Roosevelt Reach in Washington State in the 1990s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000).

To address these concerns, the Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative (UCWSRI) was established in 2000 and produced an Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Plan (UCWSRP) in 2002, which is compliant with the Endangered Species Act (ESA) and Species at Risk Act (SARA) legislation. The goal of UCWSRI is to ensure the persistence and viability of naturally reproducing populations of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River and restore opportunities for beneficial use if feasible.

Lake Roosevelt Subyearling White Sturgeon Gill Net Surveys are a key component of these efforts. These surveys aim to accomplish two primary objectives: 1) document annual natural recruitment, and 2) evaluate the relative survival of experimental larval releases as part of proposed research to test hypotheses relating to post-hatch dispersal. The surveys will be standardized, coordinated, and conducted simultaneously with efforts by the Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project and those conducted in the Keenleyside Reach.

The data analysis for these surveys will be completed by the STOI's Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project per their project protocol, which has yet to be developed. It is important to note that our frame represents the target population of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt and focuses on monitoring annual natural recruitment through standardized gill net surveys.
objectives:
Objective 1: Monitor annual natural recruitment of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt.

Detailed Description:
1. Conduct regular gill net surveys to document the number of newly recruited white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt each year.
2. Collaborate with the Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project and Keenleyside Reach surveys to ensure standardization and coordination of data collection efforts.
3. Analyze survey data by the STOI's Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project, using their yet-to-be-developed project protocol.
